title: Michelle Odinet
text:
Michelle Miller Odinet (born ) is an American lawyer who was elected as a <a href="Lafayette%2C%20Louisiana">Lafayette, Louisiana</a> City Court Judge in November 2020. Odinet was previously an <a href="Assistant%20District%20Attorney">assistant district attorney</a> in New Orleans and Lafayette and a <a href="Public%20defender%20%28United%20States%29">public defender</a>. She resigned from her judgeship on December 31, 2021, days after a video surfaced of her repeatedly using a racial slur.
Early life.
Michelle Marie Miller was born in <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a>, the daughter of <a href="Metairie%2C%20Louisiana">Metairie</a> attorney M.O. Miller II and his wife Diane. The extended Miller family have "deep roots" in New Orleans, and in 1989, Odinet was "crowned <a href="Mardi_Gras_in_New_Orleans%23Social_clubs">Queen of the Hermes Ball</a>." She completed a B.A. at <a href="H.%20Sophie%20Newcomb%20Memorial%20College">H. Sophie Newcomb Memorial College</a> in 1990 and a J.D. at <a href="Tulane%20University%20Law%20School">Tulane University Law School</a> in 1993.
Career.
Odinet joined the New Orleans district attorney's office as a prosecutor part time in June 1991. She became a full-time assistant assistant attorney in November 1993. From September to December 1996, Odinet was a part-time worker for the indigent defender program. In December 1996, following the resignation of Robin Rhodes, Mike Harson, the fifteenth judicial district attorney, named Odinet as the new assistant district attorney. In this role, she served as a <a href="prosecutor">prosecutor</a> of misdemeanors. 
Odinet worked at a private <a href="law%20firm">law firm</a> where she managed insurance defense cases. Odinet took a break from her career to <a href="Homeschooling%20in%20the%20United%20States">homeschool</a> her four children. In the fall of 2019, she returned to the <a href="Lafayette%20Parish%2C%20Louisiana">Lafayette Parish, Louisiana</a> public defender's office. 
In 2020, Odinet was elected to a six-year term as Lafayette City Court Judge, Division A. She ran as a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> and succeeded Francie Bouillion. Odinet won 56 percent (32,104) of the vote to <a href="Nonpartisanism%20in%20the%20United%20States">nonpartisan</a> Jules Edwards III's 43 percent (24,237). In December 2021, Odinet took an unpaid <a href="leave%20of%20absence">leave of absence</a> following the surfacing of a video of her using racist language in her home. Odinet issued a statement that she was on a sedative at the time and had no recollection of the event. The <a href="Louisiana%20Supreme%20Court">Louisiana Supreme Court</a> appointed <a href="Vanessa%20Harris">Vanessa Harris</a> to replace Odinet from December 17, 2021 through February 28, 2022.
In December 2021, the New Orleans district attorney, Jason Williams, ordered a review of all of Odinet's New Orleans cases by the civil rights division in his office. Odinet resigned from the bench on December 31, 2021.
Personal life.
In 1996, Odinet was a resident of <a href="Lafayette%2C%20Louisiana">Lafayette, Louisiana</a>. She is married to plastic surgeon and <a href="otolaryngologist">otolaryngologist</a> Kenneth Louis Odinet, Jr.. Odinet is the son of Kenneth Odinet, Sr., who served as the state representative for <a href="St.%20Bernard%20Parish%2C%20Louisiana">St. Bernard Parish</a> in the <a href="Louisiana%20House%20of%20Representatives">Louisiana House of Representatives</a> from 1987 to 2007 as a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a>, though he changed his party affiliation to <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> when he ran for <a href="Louisiana%20Public%20Service%20Commission">Public Service Commissioner</a> in 2008 and lost. Odinet has four children, two sets of boy/girl twins.
